body: Every time someone communicates to me about what I can or cannot do, my quiet inside voice always says -why not?
body_html: Every time someone communicates to me about what I can or cannot do, my quiet inside voice always says -why not?
title: The Why Not Girl

author.bio: Warrior of God, Helper of Man, Agitator of Souls.  Raised on computers, now living as a nomad.
author.bio_html: Warrior of God, Helper of Man, Agitator of Souls. Raised on computers, now living as a nomad.

body:
Whether a person can or can't do something should not be the question, but rather if a person should or shouldn't.

Beyond that, you could say its a matter of statistics.  Why can't you win the lottery? Why can't you win a million dollars off roulette? Because statistically, nobody wins; except of course those who run it.
body_html:

Beyond that, you could say its a matter of statistics. Why can't you win the lottery? Why can't you win a million dollars off roulette? Because statistically, nobody wins; except of course those who run it.

author.bio: Warrior of God, Helper of Man, Agitator of Souls.  Raised on computers, now living as a nomad.
author.bio_html: Warrior of God, Helper of Man, Agitator of Souls. Raised on computers, now living as a nomad.

body:
Yes, and does my answer not apply?

As for what other people say, 99% of the time they are misinformed, and even when they are more or less right, they still word the thing poorly.

I raise my daughter to be physically capable, and i teach her math as well as science.  Having said that, i will raise her primarily as a Christian, to the extent that she continue in the faith of Jesus Christ, forcing nothing on her except my love towards her.

Now having said **that**, and assuming she does not rebel, i would expect and advise her to be a wife, and to not pursue vain "careers" but rather to marry a man and raise a family of her own in the love of God.

This does not mean that she can't do anything, but it also does not mean she can do anything.  Our capacity to do anything means nothing in light of what makes most sense for us to do, and what will be best for us in the long run.
body_html:
Yes, and does my answer not apply?

As for what other people say, 99% of the time they are misinformed, and even when they are more or less right, they still word the thing poorly.

I raise my daughter to be physically capable, and i teach her math as well as science. Having said that, i will raise her primarily as a Christian, to the extent that she continue in the faith of Jesus Christ, forcing nothing on her except my love towards her.

Now having said that, and assuming she does not rebel, i would expect and advise her to be a wife, and to not pursue vain "careers" but rather to marry a man and raise a family of her own in the love of God.

This does not mean that she can't do anything, but it also does not mean she can do anything. Our capacity to do anything means nothing in light of what makes most sense for us to do, and what will be best for us in the long run.

body:
> Now having said that, and assuming she does not rebel, i would expect and advise her to be a wife, and to not pursue vain "careers" but rather to marry a man and raise a family of her own in the love of God.

Jesus would disagree with you, read Matthew 19:12. Paul would also take issues with this compulsory marriage doctrine, check out 1 Corinthians 7.

Now having said that, and assuming she does not rebel, i would expect and advise her to be a wife, and to not pursue vain "careers" but rather to marry a man and raise a family of her own in the love of God.

body: The only thing girls can't do as well as boys is play sports, because they have less strength and less physio-spatial awareness. And even that doesn't always matter because they don't compete against boys in the first place. Pretty much everything else girls will always be way better at than boys, because they have more brain power. They are not the expendable machines who sacrifice themselves to work and fight so they don't have to give up their personal development. The reason so many men say the opposite is because we're extremely jealous, but we also like to be proud and show no weakness so most of us won't admit it.
body_html: The only thing girls can't do as well as boys is play sports, because they have less strength and less physio-spatial awareness. And even that doesn't always matter because they don't compete against boys in the first place. Pretty much everything else girls will always be way better at than boys, because they have more brain power. They are not the expendable machines who sacrifice themselves to work and fight so they don't have to give up their personal development. The reason so many men say the opposite is because we're extremely jealous, but we also like to be proud and show no weakness so most of us won't admit it.

body:
I said that insofar as the average person will get married, and that it is only for some to be without a husband or a wife.  The main point being that i would discourage her from pursuing a "career," because her capacity to pursue one does not mean it is in her best interest.

To pursue that matter of marriage specifically would be tangential to what i remember the main point of this discussion being.

I said that insofar as the average person will get married, and that it is only for some to be without a husband or a wife. The main point being that i would discourage her from pursuing a "career," because her capacity to pursue one does not mean it is in her best interest.

To pursue that matter of marriage specifically would be tangential to what i remember the main point of this discussion being.

body:
No, I'm sincerely wondering why you view being unmarried as a problem, an attitude which I inferred from your previous comments because you said you see everything that distracts from the goal of marriage as a vanity. And while you did say that for some people living without a husband or wife is for them, you have already decided that it is not in the best interests of your children:

> I said that insofar as the average person will get married, and that it is only for some to be without a husband or a wife. The main point being that i would discourage her from pursuing a "career," because her capacity to pursue one does not mean it is in her best interest.
body_html:
No, I'm sincerely wondering why you view being unmarried as a problem, an attitude which I inferred from your previous comments because you said you see everything that distracts from the goal of marriage as a vanity. And while you did say that for some people living without a husband or wife is for them, you have already decided that it is not in the best interests of your children:

I said that insofar as the average person will get married, and that it is only for some to be without a husband or a wife. The main point being that i would discourage her from pursuing a "career," because her capacity to pursue one does not mean it is in her best interest.
